functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: How many of the top five heaviest animals live in Africa?
How many of the top five heaviest animals live in Africa?
Let me search for information about the heaviest animals to answer this question.

msg.content: Let me search for a more specific article.

<document>
<title>Largest and heaviest animals</title>
<fragment>

The heaviest land animals are all mammals. The African elephant is now listed as two species, the African bush elephant and the African forest elephant, as they are now generally considered to be two separate species.[22]





| Rank
 | Animal
 | Average mass[tonnes]
 | Maximum mass[tonnes]
 | Average total length[m (ft)]
 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | African bush elephant | 6[23][24] | 10.4[25] | 7 (23)[26] |
| 2 | Asian elephant | 4.5[1][27] | 8.15[1] | 6.8 (22.3)[27] |
| 3 | African forest elephant | 2.7[28] | 6.0[28] | 6.2 (20.3)[29] |
| 4 | White rhinoceros | 2[30][31] | 4.5[32] | 4.4 (14.4)[33] |
| 5 | Indian rhinoceros | 1.9[34][35] | 4.0[36] | 4.2 (13.8)[37] |
| 6 | Hippopotamus | 1.8[38][39] | 3.6[40] | 5.05 (16.5)[41] |
| 7 | Black rhinoceros | 1.1[42] | 2.9[43] | 4 (13.1)[44] |
| 8 | Javan rhinoceros | 1.75[45][46] | 2.3[47] | 3.8 (12.5)[48] |
| 9 | Giraffe | 1.0[1] | 2[49] | 5.15 (16.9)[50] |
| 10 | Gaur | 0.95[51] | 1.5[51] | 3.8 (12.5)[52] |


## Vertebrates[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

The African bush elephant (*Loxodonta africana*) is the largest living land animal. A native of various open habitats in sub-Saharan Africa, males weigh about 6.0 tonnes (13,200 lb) on average.[9] The largest elephant ever recorded was shot in Angola in 1974. It was a male measuring 10.67 metres (35.0 ft) from trunk to tail and 4.17 metres (13.7 ft) lying on its side in a projected line from the highest point of the shoulder, to the base of the forefoot, indicating a standing shoulder height of 3.96 metres (13.0 ft). This male had a computed weight of 10.4 tonnes.[1]




## Heaviest living animals[edit]


The heaviest living animals are all whales. Since no scale can accommodate the whole body of a large whale, most have been weighed by parts.






</fragment>
<fragment>
| Rank
 | Animal
 | Average mass[tonnes]
 | Maximum mass[tonnes]
 | Average total length[m (ft)]
 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Blue whale | 110[10] | 190[1] | 24 (79)[11] |
| 2 | North Pacific right whale | 60[12] | 120[1] | 15.5 (51)[10] |
| 3 | Southern right whale | 58[10] | 110[13] | 15.25 (50)[10] |
| 4 | Fin whale | 57[10] | 120[13] | 19.5 (64)[10] |
| 5 | Bowhead whale | 54.5[10][14] | 120[1] | 15 (49)[10] |
| 6 | North Atlantic right whale | 54[10][15] | 110[13][16] | 15 (49)[10][16] |
| 7 | Sperm whale | 31.25[10][17] | 80[1] | 13.25 (43.5)[10][17] |
| 8 | Humpback whale | 29[10][18] | 48[19] | 13.5 (44)[10] |
| 9 | Sei whale | 22.5[10] | 45[20] | 14.8 (49)[10] |
| 10 | Gray whale | 19.5[10] | 45[21] | 13.5 (44)[10] |


![](image)Infographic showing the size of marine megafauna.
![](image)The blue whale is the heaviest living animal.
## Heaviest terrestrial animals[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
50. **^** Giraffe. The Animal Files
51. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Smith, A. T., Xie, Y. (eds.) (2008) *A Guide to the Mammals of China*. Princeton University Press, Princeton Oxfordshire. p. 472 ISBN 0691099847

53. **^** "Largest mammal".

56. **^** Fortelius, M.; Kappelman, J. (1993). "The largest land mammal ever imagined". *Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society*. **108**: 85–101. doi:10.1111/j.1096-3642.1993.tb02560.x.`{{cite journal}}`: CS1 maint: multiple names: authors list (link)
57. **^** "An Ancient Elephant May Have Been Biggest Land Mammal Ever". 17 July 2015. Retrieved 21 April 2017.

</fragment>
<fragment>
25. **^** Larramendi, A. (2016). "Shoulder height, body mass and shape of proboscideans" (PDF). *Acta Palaeontologica Polonica*. **61**. doi:10.4202/app.00136.2014. S2CID 2092950. Archived (PDF) from the original on 24 August 2016.
26. **^** African Elephant. The Animal Files
27. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Shoshani, J. and Eisenberg, J. F. Elephas maximus. Archived 30 April 2013 at the Wayback Machine Mammalian Species (1982) 182:1–8
28. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Forest elephant videos, photos and facts – Loxodonta cyclotis Archived 24 October 2014 at the Wayback Machine. ARKive
29. **^** Forest Elephant Loxodonta cyclotis – Appearance/Morphology: Measurement and Weight (Literature Reports). Wildpro.twycrosszoo.org Archived 11 May 2013 at the Wayback Machine
30. **^** "White Rhino - Species - WWF". *World Wildlife Fund*. Retrieved 14 June 2017.
31. **^** White rhinoceros videos, photos and facts – Ceratotherium simum Archived 9 May 2015 at the Wayback Machine. ARKive (6 August 2004)

</fragment>
<fragment>
The **largest animal** currently alive is the blue whale. The maximum recorded weight was 190 tonnes for a specimen measuring 27.6 metres (91 ft), whereas longer ones, up to 33.6 metres (110 ft), have been recorded but not weighed.[1][2][3] It is estimated, this individual could have a mass of 250 tonnes.[4][5] The longest non-colonial animal is the lion's mane jellyfish (36.6m / 120 ft).[6]


In 2023, paleontologists estimated that the extinct whale *Perucetus*, discovered in Peru, may have outweighed the blue whale, with a mass of 85-340 t (84-335 long tons; 94-375 short tonnes.)[7] While controversial, estimates for the weight of the sauropod *Bruhathkayosaurus* suggest it was around 110-170 tons, with the highest estimate being 240 tons, if scaled with *Patagotitan*, although actual fossil remains no longer exist, and that estimation is based on described dimensions in 1987.[8] The upper estimates of weight for these two prehistoric animals would have easily rivaled or exceeded the blue whale. 


</fragment>
<fragment>

The largest land mammal extant today is the African bush elephant. The largest extinct land mammal known was long considered to be *Paraceratherium orgosensis*, a rhinoceros relative thought to have stood up to 4.8 m (15.7 ft) tall, measured over 7.4 m (24.3 ft) long and may have weighed about 17 tonnes.[55][56] In 2015, a study suggested that one example of the proboscidean *Palaeoloxodon namadicus* may have been the largest land mammal ever, based on extensive research of fragmentary leg bone fossils from one individual, with a maximum estimated size of 22 tonnes.[57][55]



### Stem-mammals (Synapsida)[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

| 2 | Nile crocodile | 410 (900)[82] | 1,090 (2,400)[1] | 4.2 (13.8)[82] |
| 3 | Orinoco crocodile | 380 (840)[*citation needed*] | 1,100 (2,400)[*citation needed*] | 4.1 (13.5)[83][84] |
| 4 | Leatherback sea turtle | 364 (800)[85][86] | 932 (2,050)[1] | 2.0 (6.6)[1] |
| 5 | American crocodile | 336 (740)[87] | 1,000 (2,200)[88] | 4.0 (13.1)[89][90] |
| 6 | Black caiman | 300 (661)[*citation needed*] | 1,000 (2,200)[*citation needed*] | 3.9 (12.8)[91][92][93][94] |
| 7 | Gharial | 250 (550)[95] | 1,000 (2,200)[96] | 4.5 (14.8)[95] |
| 8 | American alligator | 240 (530)[97][98] | 1,000 (2,200)[1] | 3.4 (11.2)[98] |
| 9 | Mugger crocodile | 225 (495)[97] | 700 (1,500)[99] | 3.3 (10.8)[98] |
| 10 | False gharial | 210 (460)[100] | 590 (1,300)[101] | 4.0 (13.1)[102] |

</fragment>

<fragment>

1. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** ***e*** ***f*** ***g*** ***h*** ***i*** ***j*** ***k*** ***l*** ***m*** ***n*** ***o*** ***p*** ***q*** ***r*** ***s*** ***t*** ***u*** ***v*** ***w*** ***x*** ***y*** ***z*** ***aa*** ***ab*** ***ac*** ***ad*** ***ae*** ***af*** ***ag*** ***ah*** ***ai*** ***aj*** ***ak*** ***al*** ***am*** ***an*** ***ao*** ***ap*** ***aq*** ***ar*** ***as*** ***at*** ***au*** ***av*** ***aw*** ***ax*** ***ay*** ***az*** ***ba*** ***bb*** ***bc*** ***bd*** ***be*** ***bf*** ***bg*** ***bh*** ***bi*** ***bj*** ***bk*** Wood, Gerald *The Guinness Book of Animal Facts and Feats* (1983) ISBN 978-0-85112-235-9
2. **^** Davies, Ella (20 April 2016). "The longest animal alive may be one you never thought of". *BBC Earth*. Retrieved 14 February 2018.

</fragment>
<fragment>

### Mammals (Mammalia)[edit]


Main article: List of largest mammals

![](image)Size of *Paraceratherium* (dark grey) compared to a human and other rhinos (though one study suggests *Palaeoloxodon namadicus* may have been a larger land mammal)
The blue whale is the largest mammal of all time, with the largest known specimen being 33.6 m (110.2 ft) long and the largest weighted specimen being 190 tonnes.[53][54] The extinct whale species *Perucetus colossus* was shorter than the blue whale, at 17.0–20.1 meters (55.8–65.9 ft) but it is estimated to have rivaled or surpassed it in weight, at 85–340 tonnes. At the highest estimates, this would make *Perucetus* the heaviest known animal in history.[7]


</fragment>
<fragment>
Insects, a class of Arthropoda, are easily the most numerous class of organisms, with over one million identified species, and probably many undescribed species. The heaviest insect is almost certainly a species of beetle, which incidentally is the most species-rich order of organisms. Although heavyweight giant wetas (*Deinacrida heteracantha*) are known, the elephant beetles of Central and South America, (*Megasoma elephas*) and (*M. actaeon*), the Titan beetle (*Titanus giganteus*) of the neotropical rainforest or the Goliath beetles, (*Goliathus goliatus*) and (*G. regius*), of Africa's rainforest are thought to reach a higher weight.[245] The most frequently crowned are the Goliath beetles, the top known size of which is at least 100 g (3.5 oz) and 11.5 cm (4.5 in).[1] The elephant beetles and titan beetle can reach greater lengths than the Goliath, at up to 13.1 and 15.2 cm (5.2 and 6.0 in), respectively, but this is in part thanks to their rather large horns. 
</fragment>
<fragment>
| 11 | Aldabra giant tortoise | 205 (450)[103] | 360 (790)[1] | 1.4 (4.6)[104] |
| 12 | Loggerhead sea turtle | 200 (441)[*citation needed*] | 545 (1,202)[*citation needed*] | 0.95 (3.2)[104] |
| 13 | Green sea turtle | 190 (418.9)[105] | 395 (870.8)[82] | 1.12 (3.67)[82] |
| 14 | Slender-snouted crocodile | 180 (400)[106] | 325 (720)[106] | 3.3 (10.8)[106] |
| 15 | Galapagos tortoise | 175 (390)[107] | 417 (919)[108] | 1.5 (4.9)[109] |


### Dinosaurs (Dinosauria)[edit]


Main article: Dinosaur size

See also: Largest prehistoric animals

![](image)*Bruhathkayosaurus matleyi*, potentially the largest animal to have walked the earth.
![](image)A human and the longest known dinosaurs of the five major clades. Each grid section represents 1 square meter. Sauropoda (*Supersaurus vivianae*)
 Ornithopoda (*Shantungosaurus giganteus*)
 Theropoda (*Spinosaurus aegyptiacus*)
 Thyreophora (*Stegosaurus ungulatus*)
 Marginocephalia (*Triceratops prorsus*)


</fragment>
<fragment>
41. **^** Hippopotamuses, Hippopotamus Pictures, Hippopotamus Facts. Animals.nationalgeographic.com
42. **^** Black Rhinoceroses, Black Rhinoceros Pictures, Black Rhinoceros Facts. Animals.nationalgeographic.com
43. **^** Hillman-Smith, A. K. Kes; Groves, Colin P. (1994). "Diceros bicornis". *Mammalian Species* (455): 1–8. doi:10.2307/3504292. JSTOR 3504292. S2CID 253955264.
44. **^** ADW: Diceros bicornis: Information. (9 April 2009)
45. **^** Javan Rhinoceros. Animal Info (26 November 2005)
46. **^** Javan Rhino. Onehornedrhino.org Archived 13 October 2011 at the Wayback Machine
47. **^** Javan rhinoceros videos, photos and facts – Rhinoceros sondaicus Archived 27 September 2011 at the Wayback Machine. ARKive
48. **^** EDGE :: Mammal Species Information Archived 8 November 2017 at the Wayback Machine Edgeofexistence.org (12 November 2010)
49. **^** Owen-Smith, R. Norman, *Megaherbivores: The Influence of Very Large Body Size on Ecology*. Cambridge University Press (1992), ISBN 978-0-521-42637-4

</fragment>
<fragment>

The following is a list of the heaviest living bird species based on maximum reported or reliable mass, but average weight is also given for comparison. These species are almost all flightless, which allows for these particular birds to have denser bones and heavier bodies. Flightless birds comprise less than 2% of all living bird species.[*citation needed*]






</fragment>
<fragment>
This particular species of moa stood up to 3.7 m (12 ft) tall,[157] but weighed about half as much as a large elephant bird or mihirung due to its comparatively slender frame.[1]


The heaviest bird ever capable of flight was *Argentavis magnificens*, the largest member of the now extinct family Teratornithidae, found in Miocene-aged fossil beds of Argentina, with a wingspan up to 5.5 m (18 ft), a length of up to 1.25 m (4.1 ft), a height on the ground of up to 1.75 m (5.7 ft) and a body weight of at least 71 kg (157 lb).[1][162][163] *Pelagornis sandersi* is thought to have had an even larger wingspan of about 6.1–7.4 m (20–24 ft), but is only about 22–40 kg (49–88 lb), half the mass of the former.[164][163]



##### Heaviest living bird species[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
The largest ceratopsians were *Triceratops* and its ancestor *Eotriceratops* from the late Cretaceous of North America. Both estimated to have reached about 9 m (30 ft) in length[154] and weighed 12 tonnes.[155][156]
#### Birds (Aves)[edit]


Main article: List of largest birds

![](image)The common ostrich is the largest living bird.
The largest living bird, a member of the Struthioniformes, is the common ostrich (*Struthio camelus*), from the plains of Africa. A large male ostrich can reach a height of 2.8 m (9.2 ft) and weigh over 156 kg (344 lb).[157] A mass of 200 kg (440 lb) has been cited for the common ostrich but no wild ostriches of this weight have been verified.[158] Eggs laid by the ostrich can weigh 1.4 kg (3.1 lb) and are the largest eggs in the world today.[*citation needed*]


</fragment>
</document>
msg.name: search

<fragment>

The largest land mammal extant today is the African bush elephant. The largest extinct land mammal known was long considered to be *Paraceratherium orgosensis*, a rhinoceros relative thought to have stood up to 4.8 m (15.7 ft) tall, measured over 7.4 m (24.3 ft) long and may have weighed about 17 tonnes.[55][56] In 2015, a study suggested that one example of the proboscidean *Palaeoloxodon namadicus* may have been the largest land mammal ever, based on extensive research of fragmentary leg bone fossils from one individual, with a maximum estimated size of 22 tonnes.[57][55]



### Stem-mammals (Synapsida)[edit]

<fragment>

### Mammals (Mammalia)[edit]


Main article: List of largest mammals

![](image)Size of *Paraceratherium* (dark grey) compared to a human and other rhinos (though one study suggests *Palaeoloxodon namadicus* may have been a larger land mammal)
The blue whale is the largest mammal of all time, with the largest known specimen being 33.6 m (110.2 ft) long and the largest weighted specimen being 190 tonnes.[53][54] The extinct whale species *Perucetus colossus* was shorter than the blue whale, at 17.0–20.1 meters (55.8–65.9 ft) but it is estimated to have rivaled or surpassed it in weight, at 85–340 tonnes. At the highest estimates, this would make *Perucetus* the heaviest known animal in history.[7]


</fragment>
<fragment>
Insects, a class of Arthropoda, are easily the most numerous class of organisms, with over one million identified species, and probably many undescribed species. The heaviest insect is almost certainly a species of beetle, which incidentally is the most species-rich order of organisms. Although heavyweight giant wetas (*Deinacrida heteracantha*) are known, the elephant beetles of Central and South America, (*Megasoma elephas*) and (*M. actaeon*), the Titan beetle (*Titanus giganteus*) of the neotropical rainforest or the Goliath beetles, (*Goliathus goliatus*) and (*G. regius*), of Africa's rainforest are thought to reach a higher weight.[245] The most frequently crowned are the Goliath beetles, the top known size of which is at least 100 g (3.5 oz) and 11.5 cm (4.5 in).[1] The elephant beetles and titan beetle can reach greater lengths than the Goliath, at up to 13.1 and 15.2 cm (5.2 and 6.0 in), respectively, but this is in part thanks to their rather large horns. 
</fragment>
<fragment>

| 12 | Loggerhead sea turtle | 200 (441)[*citation needed*] | 545 (1,202)[*citation needed*] | 0.95 (3.2)[104] |
| 13 | Green sea turtle | 190 (418.9)[105] | 395 (870.8)[82] | 1.12 (3.67)[82] |
| 14 | Slender-snouted crocodile | 180 (400)[106] | 325 (720)[106] | 3.3 (10.8)[106] |
| 15 | Galapagos tortoise | 175 (390)[107] | 417 (919)[108] | 1.5 (4.9)[109] |


### Dinosaurs (Dinosauria)[edit]


Main article: Dinosaur size

See also: Largest prehistoric animals

![](image)*Bruhathkayosaurus matleyi*, potentially the largest animal to have walked the earth.
![](image)A human and the longest known dinosaurs of the five major clades. Each grid section represents 1 square meter. Sauropoda (*Supersaurus vivianae*)
 Ornithopoda (*Shantungosaurus giganteus*)
 Theropoda (*Spinosaurus aegyptiacus*)
 Thyreophora (*Stegosaurus ungulatus*)
 Marginocephalia (*Triceratops prorsus*)


</fragment>

44. **^** ADW: Diceros bicornis: Information. (9 April 2009)
45. **^** Javan Rhinoceros. Animal Info (26 November 2005)
46. **^** Javan Rhino. Onehornedrhino.org Archived 13 October 2011 at the Wayback Machine
47. **^** Javan rhinoceros videos, photos and facts – Rhinoceros sondaicus Archived 27 September 2011 at the Wayback Machine. ARKive
48. **^** EDGE :: Mammal Species Information Archived 8 November 2017 at the Wayback Machine Edgeofexistence.org (12 November 2010)
49. **^** Owen-Smith, R. Norman, *Megaherbivores: The Influence of Very Large Body Size on Ecology*. Cambridge University Press (1992), ISBN 978-0-521-42637-4

</fragment>
<fragment>

The following is a list of the heaviest living bird species based on maximum reported or reliable mass, but average weight is also given for comparison. These species are almost all flightless, which allows for these particular birds to have denser bones and heavier bodies. Flightless birds comprise less than 2% of all living bird species.[*citation needed*]






</fragment>
<fragment>
This particular species of moa stood up to 3.7 m (12 ft) tall,[157] but weighed about half as much as a large elephant bird or mihirung due to its comparatively slender frame.[1]


The heaviest bird ever capable of flight was *Argentavis magnificens*, the largest member of the now extinct family Teratornithidae, found in Miocene-aged fossil beds of Argentina, with a wingspan up to 5.5 m (18 ft), a length of up to 1.25 m (4.1 ft), a height on the ground of up to 1.75 m (5.7 ft) and a body weight of at least 71 kg (157 lb).[1][162][163] *Pelagornis sandersi* is thought to have had an even larger wingspan of about 6.1–7.4 m (20–24 ft), but is only about 22–40 kg (49–88 lb), half the mass of the former.[164][163]



##### Heaviest living bird species[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
The largest ceratopsians were *Triceratops* and its ancestor *Eotriceratops* from the late Cretaceous of North America. Both estimated to have reached about 9 m (30 ft) in length[154] and weighed 12 tonnes.[155][156]
#### Birds (Aves)[edit]


Main article: List of largest birds

![](image)The common ostrich is the largest living bird.
The largest living bird, a member of the Struthioniformes, is the common ostrich (*Struthio camelus*), from the plains of Africa. A large male ostrich can reach a height of 2.8 m (9.2 ft) and weigh over 156 kg (344 lb).[157] A mass of 200 kg (440 lb) has been cited for the common ostrich but no wild ostriches of this weight have been verified.[158] Eggs laid by the ostrich can weigh 1.4 kg (3.1 lb) and are the largest eggs in the world today.[*citation needed*]


</fragment>
</document>
msg.name: search

msg.content:
Based on the information provided, let me identify the top 5 heaviest animals and determine how many live in Africa:

The top 5 heaviest animals (by maximum mass) are:
1. Blue whale - 190 tonnes (marine animal)
2. North Pacific right whale - 120 tonnes (marine animal)
3. Fin whale - 120 tonnes (marine animal)
4. Bowhead whale - 120 tonnes (marine animal)
5. Southern right whale - 110 tonnes (marine animal)

Interestingly, all of the top 5 heaviest animals are whales, and none of them are exclusively African species. While some of these whales might occasionally be found in waters around Africa, they are not considered distinctly African animals.

If we were to look at the top 5 heaviest land animals instead:
1. African bush elephant - 10.4 tonnes (African)
2. Asian elephant - 8.15 tonnes
3. African forest elephant - 6.0 tonnes (African)
4. White rhinoceros - 4.5 tonnes (African)
5. Indian rhinoceros - 4.0 tonnes

Among the top 5 heaviest land animals, 3 of them are native to Africa (African bush elephant, African forest elephant, and White rhinoceros).

So to directly answer your question: None of the top 5 heaviest animals overall live exclusively in Africa, as they are all marine mammals. However, if we consider land animals, 3 out of the top 5 heaviest are African species.
